description: This course provides an introduction to real estate with a focus on investment and financing issues. Project evaluation, financing strategies, investment decision making and real estate capital markets are covered. No prior knowledge of the industry is required, but students are expected to rapidly acquire a working knowledge of real estate markets. Classes are conducted in a standard lecture format with discussion required. The course contains cases that help students evaluate the impact of more complex financing and capital markets tools used in real estate. There are case studies and two midterms, (depending on instructor).
name: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS

values.comments:
This course provides an introduction to real estate with a focus on investment and financing issues. Project evaluation, financing strategies, investment decision making and real estate capital markets are covered. No prior knowledge of the industry is required, but students are expected to rapidly acquire a working knowledge of real estate markets.
Several students said that this class helped them to develop a clear understanding of many concepts such as financial valuation of real estate. Students provided mixed reviews of the pace of the course. Some asserted that the class was relatively slow-paced, whereas others claimed that it moved too quickly and presented too much information.
Professor Wong was said to be extremely accessible and approachable. According to many, she “genuinely cares about her students” and brings “such great energy and passion to the material” thereby motivating her students. Many students did mention that this was her first time teaching and they would have preferred more structure and organization to the course.

Students claimed that the book and the materials available on Webcafe, including practice problems, exams, etc., were extremely helpful. The cases were also said to be great practice and the PowerPoint slides served as an effective study resource. However, students mentioned that the workload was heavier after the midterm. Many students noted that they considered a real estate concentration after this course and would recommend it to both majors and non-majors.
